objectives.description: Analyze the risks and returns of various saving and investment options to understand trade-offs in financial decision-making.
Determine which financial strategies align with different time horizons and personal financial goals.
Use decision-making criteria to select appropriate saving and investment vehicles for specific situations.
Recognize how personal risk tolerance influences investment choices and long-term financial outcomes.

terms.definition: A savings product with a fixed interest rate and maturity date; funds are locked in for a specific period.
terms.example: A 12-month CD paying 4% APY‚Äîwithdraw early and you pay a penalty

terms.definition: The degree of variability in investment returns that an individual is willing to accept based on their goals and situation.
terms.example: A young investor may accept more volatility; someone near retirement prefers stability

terms.definition: How quickly and easily an asset can be converted to cash without losing significant value.
terms.example: A savings account is highly liquid; real estate is not (takes time to sell)

terms.definition: Spreading investments across different asset types to reduce overall risk‚Äî"don't put all your eggs in one basket."
terms.example: Owning stocks, bonds, AND real estate instead of only one company's stock

leftPanel.title: Two Different Approaches
paragraphs: Saving focuses on security and accessibility for short-term needs‚Äîpreserving what you have.
Investing aims for growth over longer periods but involves accepting more risk for potentially higher returns.
Understanding the relationship between risk and return is essential for making informed financial choices.

highlightBox.text: � The key question: How soon do you need the money, and how much volatility can you handle?

leftPanel.title: Low-Risk Options for Short-Term Goals
paragraphs: Savings Accounts: FDIC insured, earn 0.01%-5% interest, highly liquid. Perfect for emergency funds.
Certificates of Deposit (CDs): Fixed rate for specific period, higher rates than savings, early withdrawal penalties.
Money Market Funds: Slightly higher returns, invest in short-term debt, very low risk but not FDIC insured.

highlightBox.text: � FDIC insurance protects up to $250,000 per depositor, per bank‚Äîyour money is safe!

infoCard.title: Best For:
items: Money you can't afford to lose

layoutData.title: Growing Wealth Over Time
paragraphs: Investments offer higher potential returns but come with varying levels of risk. Understanding each option helps you make informed decisions.
bulletPoints: Corporate Bonds: Loans to companies paying fixed interest; moderate risk depending on company stability
Mutual Funds: Pooled investments managed by professionals; diversification reduces risk
Index Funds: Track market indexes like S&P 500; low fees, broad diversification
Individual Stocks: Ownership in companies; highest risk but highest potential returns
Real Estate: Property investments; can provide income and appreciation over time
ETFs: Trade like stocks but offer diversification; flexible and tax-efficient

leftPanel.title: Higher Returns = Higher Risk
paragraphs: This is one of the most fundamental principles in finance: as potential return increases, so does risk.
There's no such thing as a "guaranteed" high-return investment. Anyone promising high returns with no risk is likely offering a scam.
Your job is to find the right balance between risk and return based on your goals, timeline, and comfort level.

highlightBox.text: ‚öñÔ∏è The risk-return tradeoff: More risk = potential for more reward, but also potential for more loss.

layoutData.title: Match Your Strategy to Your Timeline
paragraphs: Your time horizon‚Äîhow long until you need the money‚Äîis crucial for choosing the right strategy. Longer timelines allow you to take more risk because you have time to recover from market downturns.
bulletPoints: Short-term (1-3 years): Savings accounts, CDs, money markets‚Äîprioritize safety and liquidity
Medium-term (3-7 years): Balanced mix of bonds and conservative funds‚Äîsome growth with protection
Long-term (7+ years): Stock-heavy portfolio‚Äîmaximize growth potential, ride out volatility
Very long-term (20+ years): Aggressive growth investments‚Äîcompound returns over decades

keyPoint.text: üïê Time is your greatest asset as a young investor. Starting early gives you decades for compound growth to work its magic!

leftPanel.title: More Options Than Ever
paragraphs: Today's investors have access to tools that weren't available to previous generations. Technology has democratized investing.
You can start investing with as little as $1 using apps like Acorns, Robinhood, or Fidelity. Many platforms offer fractional shares and zero-commission trading.
However, more options also means more opportunities to make mistakes. Education and research are more important than ever.

highlightBox.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Beware of "get rich quick" schemes and meme stocks. Build wealth slowly through diversified, long-term investing.

scenario.name: Liam's Short-Term Car Savings Goal in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Liam wants to buy a car in 18 months. He has $5,000 saved but needs $8,000 total for the car he wants.
He chooses a 1-year CD with a 4% interest rate. While this won't get him to his full goal alone, it provides security and some growth while he continues to save additional money each month.

Why a CD makes sense: Liam needs the money soon (short timeline), so he can't risk losing value in the stock market. A CD offers better returns than a regular savings account while keeping his money safe.

scenario.name: Julia's Long-Term Retirement Strategy in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Julia is 17 years old and wants to start saving for retirement. She invests $1,000 in a mutual fund that historically returns 7% annually.
If she adds just $50 monthly for the next 40 years, she could have over $140,000 by retirement‚Äîeven though she only contributed about $25,000 of her own money!
Why stocks make sense: Julia has 40+ years until retirement. Short-term volatility doesn't matter‚Äîshe has time to ride out market dips and benefit from compound growth.

takeaways.title: Risk and Return Are Linked
takeaways.description: Higher potential returns always come with higher risk‚Äîthere are no shortcuts to guaranteed wealth

takeaways.title: Time Horizon Guides Strategy
